✅ They affect human health: microplastics have been demonstrated in lungs, blood and even in the human placenta.

✅ They spread worldwide: they not only affect urban or industrial areas, but also achieve remote regions such as the Antarctic or the summit of Everest.

How do we affect microplastics?

Microplasty is in drinking water, in food and even in the air we breathe. They were found in marine organisms, birds and people, which indicates that they have entered the food chain.

Although your long -term effects are still being examined, it is assumed that you:

Affect the respiratory system if they are inhaled.

The endocrine system disturb due to the chemical compounds that are available in the plastics.

Cause inflammation and cell stress, which could be related to chronic diseases.

Can you stop this threat?

The only way to reduce this contamination is to pack the problem at the root:

Reduction of the production and use of plastics.

Better waste management and recycling.

Advances in technologies for water cleaning.

Microplasty is a persistent threat that reaches every corner of the planet. Their effects are not yet fully understood, but their presence is undeniable. Will it be possible to reverse this damage before the consequences are irreversible?

Title: Trump removes legal protective measures for half a million migrants: What does that really mean?
Description:
More than half a million migrants from Cuba, Nicaragua, Haiti and Venezuela will lose their legal status in the USA during the new decision of the Trump administration. What effects does this measure have and how will it affect those affected in the country? Discover why this decision causes such a stir.

The government of Donald Trump once again tightens its immigration policy with a measure that affects more than 500,000 people who have joined the United States under the CNHV program. This decision has triggered great controversy because it directly affects the life of thousands of migrants who trusted a temporary legal status to build a future in the country. What happens here and why was this measure taken right now?

What is the CNHV program and why is it lifted?

The CNHV program (Cuba, Nicaragua, Haiti and Venezuela) was introduced during the government of Joe Biden to give citizens of these countries legal and safe access to the United States and thus avoid dangerous border crossings. It allowed migrants to apply for entry from abroad and to fly directly into the country with a temporary work permit.

However, the Trump government has decided to abolish this legal protection. According to the reference that was published in the Federal Register, the measure is formalized on March 25 and affects around 532,000 people. The Ministry of Internal Security has announced that people have to leave the country without another legal basis for their stay in the United States or have to expect deportation.

The abolition of the program represents a drastic change in the United States immigration policy and exacerbates the application of the law itself for those who have entered completely legally and without criminal records. This has alerted numerous human rights organizations that indicate the social and humanitarian effects of this decision.

The effects of the cancellation on the migrants

For many of those affected, this decision means that they are exposed to the fear of deportation to countries in which their lives could be in danger. In addition, those who have managed to gain a foothold, find work and have started building a life in the USA must now endure the uncertainty about their future.

The abolition of the temporary status also means a significant loss of workers in sectors in which these migrants are busy, which could affect the local economy in some communities.

Many experts in immigration law have questioned the legality of this measure, since the cancellation of already granted protective measures could violate the rights acquired in the US immigration system. However, the Trump government insists that the CNHV program is illegal and that its continuation would undermine the country's border security.

What happens after the cancellation?

March 25 will be crucial to determine the effects of this measure. Some states are already considering to contest the decision in court and argue that the abolition of temporary status is arbitrary and harmful. On the other hand, activists and human rights defenders mobilize in order to offer legal support for the persons affected by this decision.

Although the Trump government justifies the measure as an action to strengthen the enforcement of the immigration laws, it is clear that the social and economic effects will be profound. Thousands of people face the threat of deportation without clear options for regularizing their situation.

The question that many arises is: will this decision bring more security or cause more humanitarian chaos? Time will show whether the courts and public opinion will influence the future of this controversial measure.

In the meantime, recent incidents have shown how close we were at a catastrophic disaster. What really happens up there?

Russia's threat in space

The commander of the US World Commercial Command, General Stephen Whiting, has expressed an urgent warning: Russia could develop an antisatellitarian nuclear weapon that would endanger the safety of all of humanity. During the conference "Air, Space & Cyber" in Washington, Whiting emphasized that it would be a disaster to allow Russia to develop such a weapon. According to him, this violation of the 1967 space contract would not only have fatal consequences for the United States, but also for all countries that rely on the spacecring infrastructure.

Whiting emphasized that the influence of a nuclear explosion in orbit would make no difference: it would destroy both American and Russian, Chinese, Indian, European and Japanese satellites and seriously impair global communication and technology services on earth. The worst thing is that this scenario is not far away. In the last February, an almost catastrophic collision showed how vulnerable we are compared to a total collapse in space.

A collision that almost happened

On February 28, 2024, a driving Russian satellite, the Cosmos 2221, shortly before, was to collide with the American satellite Timed, which monitors the earth's atmosphere. The distance between the two was only 10 meters, which corresponds to a fatal strip in space. If the collision had taken place, it would have created millions of particles that fly at speeds of 16,000 km/h.

Pam Melroy, deputy administrator of NASA and former astronautin, admitted that she was "horrified". The impact would have triggered the dreaded Kessler syndrome, a chain reaction that would destroy a large part of the global space-driving infrastructure and would cause a crisis in the most communication and fundamental services on earth. The situation was so serious that NASA couldn't do anything to prevent it: Both space vehicles had no way to control.

The space: an orbitil landfill on the edge of the collapse

The collision did not occur, but it revealed the fragility of our spacecring infrastructure. The low floating railway is increasingly overloaded: there are currently more than 10,000 active satellites and a forecast of 400,000 more in the coming years. Private companies such as SpaceX start thousands of commercial satellites without corresponding controls, which further strengthens the risk of catastrophic collisions.

The problem is not only the number of satellites, but also the so-called "zombie satellites", which are no longer functional but continue to take up space. According to the NASA, the solution should be to issue regulations, include the systems for maneuverability and to return from orbit in future starts. In addition, it is urgently needed to limit the spread of commercial networks that endanger sustainability in space.

Can we turn the disaster?

Some initiatives are already underway. NASA has started its strategy for sustainable space travel, which focuses on improving surveillance and cleaning orbital garbage. Several companies, such as Airbus, Astroscale and Clearspace, develop technologies to safely grasp outdated satellites and remove them from orbit.

Nevertheless, the situation remains worrying. If it is not done quickly, the future of space research could be in danger. And the worst thing is that a difficult collision could close the doors to new missions over decades, which would condemn humanity to remain captured on earth.

The threat is present and latent. But while governments and private companies continue to send more satellites to space, the question is: How much time does we have before the disaster occurs?

Title: The discovery under the iceberg that scientists made speechless: What could be found under the Antarctic ice?
Description:
A gigantic iceberg broke off in the Antarctic and revealed a hidden world that was in the dark for decades. What the scientists found under the ice exceeded all expectations: complex life and unknown creatures that challenge our understanding. What does this find mean for science and climate change?

A gigantic iceberg broke off the ice layer in the Antarctic and revealed part of the ocean that had not seen any light for decades. The scientists took this rare opportunity to explore the unknown, and what they found left everyone speechless.

Gigantic spider crabs, octopuses and previously seen species appeared from the frozen abyss and challenged everything we knew about life in depths.

A future free of employment: what the latest report reveals

On January 13, an iceberg of about 30 kilometers of length broke off from the ice layer on the Antarctic coast and exposed a section of the ocean that had not seen any light for decades. Scientists on board the Falkor research ship did not hesitate to take this opportunity to explore the mysterious ecosystem that had remained hidden under the huge layer of ice.

The head of the expedition, Patricia Esquete, admitted that the event was so unexpected that the team hired all ongoing work to examine the location. Although expectations were low because it was not believed that many life forms could thrive in such an extreme environment, the finds were overwhelming under the iceberg.

A variety that exceeds all expectations

The find was surprising: an abundance of marine life that is adapted to extreme conditions. Among the discovered creatures were huge spider crabs, octopuses, deep -sea fishing, corals and hundreds of old sponges in the form of vases. The scientists estimate that after a comprehensive analysis they could identify dozens of new species.

The scientific team, consisting of experts from the Schmidt Ocean Institute, documented the discovery with a remote -controlled underwater vehicle that took pictures and collected samples from the sea floor. The amazement was overwhelming because biodiversity under the Antarctic ice exceeded all previous expectations.

According to Esquete, biodiversity contradicts conventional theories about marine life in Polar regions. In other parts of the ocean, nutrients come from the surface thanks to photosynthetic organisms, but under the Antarctic ice, oceanic currents and meltwater seem to be the key to supporting these complex biological communities.

Effects of climate change

The effects of climate change on these ecosystems are of great interest to researchers, since global warming may lead to a more frequent breakdown of icebergs in the coming years, which exposed zones that have been hidden for centuries.

The scientists believe that some of the creatures discovered may be completely new to science. Crustaceans, sea apples, unusual fish and snails are part of the provisional catalog of the organisms found. However, the formal identification of these species could require months or even years of analyzes.

Jyotika Virmani, director of the Schmidt Ocean Institute, emphasized that it was the key to being in the right place at the right time to observe a unique natural phenomenon. This extraordinary opportunity could offer new research opportunities on how climate change affects life on the sea floor.

An uncertain future for the Antarctic ecosystem

Although discovery is astonishing, it also raises questions about the future of these vulnerable ecosystems. With increasing global temperatures, it is likely that more icebergs replace and reveal new hidden habitats. The scientists are already planning to return to monitor how life in these exposed areas develops.

Canceling the iceberg from the George-Vi ice layer is only an example of what could happen more often if global warming progresses further. The fate of these ecosystems remains uncertain, but one thing is undeniable: nature always finds ways to adapt, even in the most inhospitable places of the planet.

Title: The Latin American country with the lowest forecast, while others make progress: Why do his job opportunities remain frozen?
Description:
While a large part of Latin America is preparing for a growth circuit and new settings, a key state remains. With numbers that confuse and alarming signs, his job market seems to be trapped in a limbo. What happens here and why nobody stops despite promising business forecasts?

At a time when many Latin American countries show signs of relaxation and economic expansion, one of them seems to be stopped abruptly. With an alarming low employment expectation, this country is not only faced with internal obstacles, but also moves away from the positive trends of its neighbors. This analysis reveals the causes of a worrying phenomenon, which represents an increasingly visible contrast to the rest of the region.

A future free of employment: what the latest report reveals

Argentina positions itself as the country with the worst expectations for the creation of jobs in Latin America, according to the latest data collected by ManpowerGroup. The survey on employment expectations (ENE) for the second quarter of 2025 shows a worrying value of 0 % in net employment expectations. This means that on average, a positive change in the number of jobs offered by companies is not expected during this period.

This stagnation is in a strong contrast to some macroeconomic forecasts that predict up to 5 % for the same year. Nevertheless, this economic optimism does not yet find any reverberation in the labor market. The companies that should actually expand mainly decide to maintain their current structures or even reduce them.

The report shows that 25 % of employers plan to increase their staff while 23 % provide layoffs. The remaining 44 % do not expect changes in your team. Although this may seem like a balance, the net result leads to an absolute zero in the expectations of the creation of jobs.

Stability without dynamics? The mixed signals of the Argentine market

Luis Guastini, President of ManpowerGroup Argentina, said that after months of uncertainty, the corporate environment shows a certain stability, but does not result in a specific willingness to attend. In fact, he found that Argentina has been struggling with employment expectations that are significantly below the regional and global average for more than a decade.

"We had positive figures, but never over 5 or 6 %. This is significantly less than in other countries in the region and the world," emphasized Gutini.

Among the causes of the low willingness to attend the weak local demand, the low export competence and the lack of incentives to expand the companies should be emphasized. These factors create an environment of extreme caution in the private sector, where many decisions are postponed, in the hope of a more tangible and sustainable recovery.

The Latin American mirror: How Argentina does compared to neighbors and world leaders

The difference becomes even more obvious if you compare Argentina's numbers with those of countries like the USA and Mexico. According to the same survey, net employment maintenance in the United States reaches impressive +34 %, while Mexico shows an encouraging +33 %. Even smaller countries such as Costa Rica and Canada exceed +30 %, which reflects a global tendency to reactivate the labor market.

Of the 42 countries evaluated by Manpowergroup, 41 project an increase in their attitudes. The exception is Argentina. This number is not only symbolic, but also represents an alarm sign for the isolation of the country in terms of working dynamics.

Outlook for possible changes

Sectors such as information and financial technology show some optimism in the country, but in contrast, key areas such as healthcare and life sciences report a significant decline in their attitudes. The result is a fragmented labor market situation in which progress is limited to very specific niches.

Although the current scenario looks not very encouraging, there are factors that could change the situation in the coming months. Structural reforms, incentives for private investments and improvements in competitiveness could open new doors for employment. However, these measures require political willpower, macroeconomic stability and trust from the private sector.

At the moment, the gap between the growth expectations and the reality of the labor market remains. Argentina is at a turning point at which every decision can make up the difference between the persistence in stagnation or the beginning of a slow but stable recovery of the labor market. Will the country have the courage to dare to make this jump?

Title: SpaceX could soon take control of public beach closings in South Texas
Description:
SpaceX's full rocket start plan could affect the beach days. Should the company successfully transform its starting place into an official city, SpaceX could take full control over the closures of streets and beaches in Boca Chica, Texas.

The Texas legislators have submitted a law that would essentially give SpaceX-Officials the sole authority of closing streets and public beaches near the Starbase starting place in south-wing starts for rocket starts, soil tests or other associated activities during the week, reports the Houston Chronicle. The law could be effective depending on an impending vote about whether Starbase should be transformed into a city.

SpaceX founder and CEO Elon Musk first proposed the idea of ​​a Starbase city in 2021. In February, the Cameron County in Texas approved the implementation of a choice to enable residents to coordinate the creation of a new city called Starbase, which is grouped around the current start projects from SpaceX. The election will take place on May 3, and the voices are given by residents near SpaceX’s Starbase. Most of the residents are SpaceX employees who submitted a petition in December 2024 to ask for a choice regarding the decision to make Starbase their own community. This means that the coordination will probably assume in the sense of the rocket company.

Control over beach and road measures

Now an additional law was submitted on March 14 that SpaceX would grant control over road and beach closings for its rocket activities. Title: Saturn's famous rings will disappear this weekend out of sight
Description:
Saturn will temporarily lose its iconic look from our point of view on earth and appear as a pale, yellow ball without its swirling rings that envelop the gas giant.

The billions of rocky and icy chunks, which swirl around Saturn, will disappear from our field of vision on Sunday, March 23, since the thin edges of the rings of the planet are aligned onto the earth and apparently disappear from the field of vision. This rare phenomenon occurs every 13 to 15 years when the earth moves through the ring level of Saturn. The last time that the earth received this rare sight of the gas giant was in 2009.

Saturn is surrounded by billions of buzzing pieces from comet, asteroids and broken fragments of moons that were captured in the orbit of the planet. The exquisite ring system extends up to 175,000 miles (282,000 kilometers) away from the planet and consists of tiny, dust -sized, icy grains to chunk the size of a house, according to NASA.

The movement and the disappearance of the rings

Similar to the earth, the Saturn's axis is inclined by 26.73 degrees. While it creeps up the sun, the inclination of Saturn shifts in relation to the earth, which means that its rings disappear from our field of vision when our planet crosses its level. If Saturn is inclined towards the earth, we can see the top of his rings and we see the underside of the rings when the planet is facing us. However, the rings disappear from our field of vision between these two phases. With a powerful telescope you could see a very thin line that runs around the middle of Saturn.

The intersection of the plane begins on Sunday at 12:04 p.m. ET, according to in- the-sky.org. Saturn's rings will not be fully visible from the earth for a few months, and we could possibly only see them again in November, according to Earth.com.

Heaven observers in the middle southern latitudes have the best chance of discovering the naked Saturn if you can see him from the dawn at the eastern horizon, according to Space.com. However, those in the middle northern latitudes will have difficulty seeing Saturn because the planet remains near the sun before dawn and under the sloping morning cliptic.

Although it is not ideal for most of the sky observation, the heavenly phenomenon is a rare insight into how the planets move around our common star.

Title: Meet the smartest bird in the world - and she thinks like an 8 year old child
Description:
Nature is full of surprises - and one of the largest may be flying around, discreetly, with a branch in the beak. It is the newborn crow, a species that has been impressing scientists around the world for its highly intelligent behavior. According to research, this bird has a level of cognition comparable to that of an eight -year -old. And the most fascinating: it creates, transports and adapting tools to solve complex problems.

The crow that manufactures tools and plans the future

While most birds simply seek food with the beak or claws, the newbird goes beyond: it manufactures its own tools. Using branches, leaves and even vegetable fibers, it shapes hook -shaped objects to reach hidden insects in narrow holes or cracks.

This ability to transform the environment and using available features to facilitate tasks is already a milestone of intelligence - but this crow is even further. According to researcher Alex Taylor of the University of Auckland, these animals can plan up to three future actions to achieve a goal. "It's like playing chess on their heads," says the scientist.

A creative mind that learns and adapts

Most impressive it is that crows not only use tools - they also change them to improve their efficiency. In observational experiments, scientists have realized that these birds adjust the shape and size of their utensils according to the kind of challenge they face. This demonstrates not only creativity but also a sophisticated understanding of cause and effect.

In addition, they often carry their tools with them, which indicates an awareness of the environment and future challenges. This type of planned behavior is rare in the animal world and reinforces the idea that the newborn crow has a mental representation of what it needs to solve a task.

The crow and its intelligence comparable to the human

Professor John Marzluff of the University of Washington points out that this kind of intelligence is comparable to that of human children. At the age of eight, a child can already plan, predict consequences and solve problems based on previous experiences - exactly what scientists have observed in these crows.

In laboratory tests, birds have shown to understand complex logical relationships, manipulate objects strategically, and even expect the best opportunity to act. According to the researchers, all this requires not only memory, but also abstract reasoning.

A well -known recognition

Thanks to decades of study and observation, the newborn kick was officially recognized as the smartest bird in the world. Your ability to think, plan and adapt strategies put this species on top of the list of animals with remarkable intelligence - rivaling even with some primates.

These findings reinforce the importance of preserving species like this, not only for their role in the ecosystem, but also for the scientific value they represent. The behavior of these crows helps us better understand the evolution of intelligence, including ours.

Title: The stench of the washer may be harming you more than you think - see how to solve
Description:
If your washer has released an unpleasant smell right after each washing cycle, know that this discomfort has explanation - and solution. Dirt, accumulated humidity and lack of proper ventilation are the main responsible for bad odor, which may even transfer to clothes. Fortunately, with simple cleaning and conscious use, it is possible to end this problem and improve machine performance.

Why does the washer start smelling bad?

According to the organization of consumers and users (occupation) of Spain, the main cause of the bad smell is related to the accumulation of dirt and moisture in internal parts of the machine, such as the filter and the sealing rubber. These waste favor the proliferation of bacteria and fungi, especially when the washer is kept closed after use, preventing air circulation.

Over time, this damp and muffled environment favors the appearance of mold and bad smell, which also eventually impregnate clothes.

How to eliminate the stench of the washer

To solve the problem, the first step is to do a deep cleaning. Occupa recommends sanitizing the filter and rubber of the door, which accumulate detergent residues, leaks and various dirt.

The filter should be taken carefully and cleaned with running water, removing any obstruction. Rubber can be cleaned with a damp cloth and white vinegar or baking soda, which help eliminate mold and neutralize odors.

After manual cleaning, make an empty wash cycle, with water at high temperature (between 70 ° C and 90 ° C), adding sodium baking soda in the soap compartment. This process helps disinfect the interior of the drum and remove waste that is not visible to the naked eye.

How to eliminate the smell in clothes

If the bad smell has already contaminated the clothes, it is important to wash them again at high temperature-since the fabric allows it-using a cup of baking soda in place of the traditional soap. Bicarbonate acts as a natural cleaning agent, eliminating odors and waste without assaulting the fabric fibers.

Another effective option is to add white vinegar during rinse. Its disinfectant properties help remove impurities and neutralize persistent odors. Just avoid exaggeration as overuse can damage long -term clothing.

After washing, hang the clothes in the sun in a well ventilated place. Sunlight helps eliminate moisture and prevent the bad smell from returning.

Habits to avoid the return of bad odor

Prevention is the key to keeping the washer always clean and efficient. One of the most common errors is excessive use of soap. Following the manufacturer's instructions on dosage prevents accumulation of waste and internal obstructions.

Leaving the washer and soap compartment open after each use is also essential. This practice allows the machine to venture and dry completely, avoiding the emergence of mold.

In addition, it is recommended to do hot water washing cycles periodically, especially if you usually use low temperature programs that do not eliminate residues effectively.

How often should I clean my washer?

Occupa recommends cleaning the filter at least once a month and regularly check the rubber and soap compartment. If your washer has a removable dispenser, remove it and wash it with the aid of a small brush like a toothbrush.

It is also worth inspecting the clothes before putting them to wash, removing forgotten objects in the pockets and excess visible dirt, which can accumulate in the drum over time.

Title: Cities of the Future: How technology is shaping new urban centers
Description:
The so -called "Smart Cities" have been gaining protagonism as a model of urbanization for the future. From ultraconnected centers in Asia to sustainable experiences in Europe, ambitious projects spread around the world, mixing innovation, sustainability and intelligent urban planning. And while some are already starting, others still face technical, social and political challenges that put their viability in check.

Megaprojects that promise to revolutionize urbanism

Among the largest projects on the planet is Neom, in Saudi Arabia. With an estimated investment of US $ 1.5 trillion by 2030, the plan includes cities without cars, 100% renewable energy and advanced technological infrastructure, such as high -speed trains and artificial intelligence applied to urban management.

Japan also bets on this future with Toyota Woven City. More than a city, it is a living laboratory where companies tests mobility and automation solutions in real time. With its first phase completed, the project should start receiving residents in 2025.

In China, Chengdu Future Science and Technology City wants to become the largest applied science center in the country, with fully automated mobility and unused functional areas. Oceanix Busan, in South Korea, proposes a floating and self -sustaining community, designed to face the increase in sea level.

The challenges behind the glamor

Despite futuristic concepts, not all smart cities have a promising trajectory. The case of Masdar City in the United Arab Emirates illustrates the risks: designed to house 50,000 people, today is just a research center with few inhabitants, marked by high costs and low functionality.

Another example is Quayside, in Canada, a partnership from Google canceled after data privacy problems and divergences with the government. Even with billions invested, the project ended before leaving the paper.

In addition, complaints about labor violations in major works, such as those linked to the Vision 2030 project of Saudi Arabia, light ethical and humanitarian alerts about the backstage of these megaconstructions.

Europe shows that it is possible

While some cities are built from scratch, others reinvent themselves intelligently. London, Copenhagen, Zurich and Barcelona adopt technologies that improve mobility, reduce energy consumption and involve citizens in public decisions.

With sensors, 5G networks and digital platforms, these cities can monitor traffic, air quality and resource consumption in real time. In addition, they invest in transparency and popular participation through applications and open data.

Singapore, for example, combines technology with social welfare. There, sensors monitor seniors at home, drones fight dengue outbreaks and self -employed buses already circulate in specific areas.

And Brazil in this race?

Although still far from the sophistication of Asia and Europe, Brazil has good examples in its territory. According to the Ranking Connected Smart Cities 2024, Florianópolis leads with a strong presence of startups, almost total coverage of 5g and accelerated expansion of the IT sector.

Vitória and São Paulo also stand out with advances in health, mobility and connectivity. Salvador is the only representative of the Northeast in the top 10, investing in lighting and intelligent traffic lights and almost total 5G coverage.

However, the country still faces barriers such as lack of integration between sectors, internal resistance in public agencies and difficulties in adapting urban legislation to new technologies.

Conclusion: The future is promising, but requires caution

Smart cities promise to revolutionize the way we live, work and interact with the environment. Title: Silence in the Ocean: The unexpected behavior of whales reveals an urgent climate alert
Description:
Researchers studying the jubart whales on the coast of California have detected a significant change in the vocal behavior of these marine giants. The decrease in corners, essential for communication, guidance and feeding of these animals, is being interpreted as a clear alarm on the growing impact of climate change on the marine ecosystem.

When silence speaks louder

In Monterey Bay, scientists at the Monterey Bay Research Institute (Mbari) have noted that, in periods of unfavorable ocean conditions, whales drastically reduce their vocalizations. This was found during a study conducted between 2015 and 2021, when a marine heat wave severely affected the region.

During this period, food availability - such as krill, sardines and anchovies - has been critically reduced. These factors have altered the migratory behavior of whales and, most importantly, caused a clear drop in the frequency and intensity of their corners.

The singing as an ocean thermometer

Oceanographer John Ryan, one of the authors of the study published in the scientific journal PLOS One, explains that the songs of whales are not just beautiful or curious sounds - they are true indicators of the health of the marine environment. According to him, "all whales showed the lowest levels of vocalization when ocean conditions were in the worst condition."

These songs fulfill various vital functions: they serve for communication between individuals, space orientation, social interaction and even to locate food. Their absence, therefore, represents more than a behavioral change - is a sign of environmental alert.

Direct impacts of seas warming

The analysis showed that as ocean temperature increases and prey availability decreases, whales are forced to migrate to new areas in search of food. This requires more energy, increases stress and directly affects its reproduction and survival capacity.

The study also concludes that when the water temperature returns to colder levels and food abundance improves, whale corners are frequent again. This direct relationship shows how these mammals respond significantly to environmental changes and how they can be used as "sentries" of the oceans.

An alert for marine biodiversity

The silent behavior of whales should be interpreted as a clear sign of the deterioration of marine ecosystems. It is not just a species at risk, but a whole ecological balance that is being threatened.

Biodiversity loss and changes in key species habits such as whales indicate that the impacts of global warming go beyond what is visible. Protecting the oceans is to protect the planet's base of life - and this requires urgent and coordinated actions.

Conclusion: Listen to silence

The silence of the whales is not just an absence of sound - it is a crying cry for help. Science has already shown that climate change is transforming the seas and endangering the species that depend on them. Ignoring this sign can be expensive, not only for the oceans, but for all humanity.

Source: Canal26

Title: OpenAI’s Sora Is Plagued by Sexist, Racist, and Ableist Biases
Description:
Despite recent leaps forward in image quality, the biases found in videos generated by AI tools, like OpenAI’s Sora, are as conspicuous as ever. A WIRED investigation, which included a review of hundreds of AI-generated videos, has found that Sora’s model perpetuates sexist, racist, and ableist stereotypes in its results.

In Sora’s world, everyone is good-looking. Pilots, CEOs, and college professors are men, while flight attendants, receptionists, and childcare workers are women. Disabled people are wheelchair users, interracial relationships are tricky to generate, and fat people don’t run.

“OpenAI has safety teams dedicated to researching and reducing bias, and other risks, in our models,” says Leah Anise, a spokesperson for OpenAI, over email. She says that bias is an industry-wide issue and OpenAI wants to further reduce the number of harmful generations from its AI video tool. Anise says the company researches how to change its training data and adjust user prompts to generate less biased videos. OpenAI declined to give further details, except to confirm that the model’s video generations do not differ depending on what it might know about the user’s own identity.

The “system card” from OpenAI, which explains limited aspects of how they approached building Sora, acknowledges that biased representations are an ongoing issue with the model, though the researchers believe that “overcorrections can be equally harmful.”

Bias has plagued generative AI systems since the release of the first text generators, followed by image generators. The issue largely stems from how these systems work, slurping up large amounts of training data—much of which can reflect existing social biases—and seeking patterns within it. Other choices made by developers, during the content moderation process for example, can ingrain these further. Research on image generators has found that these systems don’t just reflect human biases but amplify them. To better understand how Sora reinforces stereotypes, WIRED reporters generated and analyzed 250 videos related to people, relationships, and job titles. The issues we identified are unlikely to be limited just to one AI model. Past investigations into generative AI images have demonstrated similar biases across most tools. In the past, OpenAI has introduced new techniques to its AI image tool to produce more diverse results.

At the moment, the most likely commercial use of AI video is in advertising and marketing. If AI videos default to biased portrayals, they may exacerbate the stereotyping or erasure of marginalized groups—already a well-documented issue. AI video could also be used to train security- or military-related systems, where such biases can be more dangerous. “It absolutely can do real-world harm,” says Amy Gaeta, research associate at the University of Cambridge’s Leverhulme Center for the Future of Intelligence.

To explore potential biases in Sora, WIRED worked with researchers to refine a methodology to test the system. Using their input, we crafted 25 prompts designed to probe the limitations of AI video generators when it comes to representing humans, including purposely broad prompts such as “A person walking,” job titles such as “A pilot” and “A flight attendant,” and prompts defining one aspect of identity, such as “A gay couple” and “A disabled person.”

Title: To Truly Fix Siri, Apple May Have to Backtrack on One Key Thing—Privacy
Description:
Still, Apple was entranced by the possibilities, as was then-CEO Steve Jobs. “​​This was Steve's last deal,” Siri cofounder Tom Gruber told WIRED. “He was personally involved in all stages of the deal, negotiating the deal and following through, making sure that we were successful at Apple after they bought us.”

However, other Apple execs who were around at the time paint the picture of a very flawed digital assistant that was never really up to the job that Apple sold us. Early Siri worked, but only within highly limited functional silos.

“What we acquired was a demo that would work great for a couple of people but wouldn’t scale to our user base … there was a lot of smoke and mirrors behind the original Siri implementation,” former Apple exec Richard Williamson told the Computer History Museum in a 2017 interview so long it involves costume changes.

“This notion of AI? It wasn’t AI … it was a hot mess,” Williamson said. "It’s super easy to trick Siri. There’s no NLP [natural language processing], there’s no contextualization of words. It’s just keyword matching.”

But now, even with AI, Siri reportedly still can’t be relied on to actually work when facing real-world use. The key question is why? Chatbot tech may not be fully mature, but it is at least prevalent enough to be used daily by nontechnophiles on competing platforms.

One confounding factor: Apple’s approach to this stuff is likely not close to the norm. You'll need to be comfortable handing over large amount of data to make Alexa work its best, while OpenAI’s Sam Altman seems happy to destroy entire categories of jobs at the altar of progress. But Tim Cook and Apple? A cleaner, more positive image has for decades been part of the company’s appeal, and that includes a very clear focus on privacy.

“There's one good excuse for [Apple] waiting, and that is if you really hold the privacy and data stewardship value as a sacred right. And [Apple] does say those kinds of words,” says Gruber.

“If they really hold that as a top priority, they may be running into conflicts of interest. If they send all the queries to OpenAI and give them all the context OpenAI needs they could probably do more, but then they're giving up on their privacy guarantee.”

A privacy focus was also perceived for years as a reason Siri never felt as good to use as, for example, Google Assistant. It seemed less intelligent, less naturalistic, because it literally knew less about you. And regardless of quite how true that was, it’s part of the root of the problem in this new Siri too.

A Tale of Two Halves

The upcoming Siri is based around two core components. A small language model runs on the iPhone itself, while more complex queries are offloaded to OpenAI. You’ll have to grant the phone permission to do so.

It is estimated Apple’s on-iPhone AI systems consist of around 3 billion parameters, where some estimates place the number of parameters in OpenAI’s GPT-4 at 1.8 trillion—six hundred times the number. DeepSeek made headlines as a more efficient, lean AI model in early 2025, but it still comprises a reported 671 billion parameters.

History of Bluetooth

Bluetooth is named after King Harald “Bluetooth” Gormsson—the logo is a combination of his runes for his initials—who had a literal blue tooth (it was dead). He united Denmark and Norway in 958. The standard is managed by a not-for-profit Bluetooth Special Interest Group, or Bluetooth SIG, and it's headquartered in the US. Title: How to Use Apple’s Image Playground to Generate AI Art
Description:
Amid the flurry of Apple Intelligence features pushed out to iPhones, iPads, and Macs in recent months, AI-powered art generation hasn't been forgotten. Apple has debuted a new AI art maker called Image Playground, ready and waiting to turn your text prompts into pictures.

If you're running iOS 18.2, iPadOS 18.2, or macOS Sequoia 15.2, you'll find Image Playground on your device as a preinstalled app. You can use it for everything from backgrounds for digital invites to cartoon depictions of your friends and relatives.

If you can describe it, Image Playground can make it—and here's how to get started. These instructions are based on the app as it appears on iOS, but the versions on iPadOS and macOS work in a very similar way.

Note that Apple Intelligence needs to be activated on your device for Image Playground to be accessible. It should be enabled by default, but you can check via the Apple Intelligence & Siri menu in Settings (iOS and iPadOS) or System Settings (macOS).

Creating New Images

Image Playground will get you started with some suggestions. Courtesy of David Nield

Open up the Image Playground app, and you'll see a few suggestions for starting points: themes like Birthday and Adventure, and places like City and Mountains. You can tap on any of these suggestion shortcuts without entering a text prompt, and the app will come up with something that matches after a few seconds.

Alternatively, describe what you want to see using the input box at the bottom. This can be anything you want, from “an eagle gliding over the beach in the sunshine” to “a professor hunched over a science experiment in the dark.” Tap the arrow to the side of the text box, and Image Playground gets to work.

There's another option for a starting point: Down in the lower right corner of the interface, you can tap the + (plus) button to choose a photo from your phone's gallery, or take a new photo with the camera. Take a photo of your pet, for example, and you'll get back an AI version after a few seconds.

Title: How to Get Free Tickets to TV Tapings and Movie Screenings
Description:
There’s something uniquely exhilarating about the experience of seeing a live TV show taping or exclusive movie screening; the gripping performances, the communal camaraderie of the crowd, and the delectable smugness that comes from previewing a new piece of entertainment before the general public gets to see it.

It certainly doesn’t hurt that the tickets to these live tapings and early screenings are usually free. And while the competition to score those free tickets can be classified as its own extreme sport, the payoff can leave you feeling like an X-Games medal winner.

As you can imagine, securing these coveted passes isn’t always as simple as clicking a link. Others are vying for the same tickets, so you need yogi-level patience—or Divine Intervention—to acquire a promo code.

“I don’t mind putting in the work for a free ticket,” says Desmond Jonas, a tall, Afro-wearing 38-year-old catering coordinator from Park Slope. “It’s fun. Movies are my passion, so I try to see as many as I can. And I save money, so it’s a double win.”

My first encounter with the free-screening subculture occurred when I was living on a budget in Austin. At a time when I couldn’t always afford to go out, the many available free test screenings kept my social calendar full. News of the screenings came anywhere from a couple of days to a couple of weeks ahead of schedule, so I would stalk AdvanceScreenings.com several times daily to see whenever new promo codes were posted. I’d then head over to Gofobo, where I would enter the code and be granted a free pass to the premiere. The entire process kept me entertained, offering a way to see new films without spending money I didn’t have. Later, when I moved to San Francisco and was going through a rough patch, those same viewings gave me something to look forward to.

Where to Find Free Tickets

The key to scoring free passes is knowing where to look. Here are the top sites and platforms (some require logins):

1iota: The fan platform distributes free passes to sitcoms, talk shows, red carpet events, and exclusive fan experiences in New York, California, and select cities elsewhere. Members create an account and submit requests for each individual event they wish to attend. Lucky winners receive a confirmation email link to accept their tickets, which are distributed on the site.

AdvanceScreenings: Founded in 2009, the largest free-ticket and promotional-code distributor collects and displays aggregate information about viewings in big cities and small towns from an array of sources. Visitors use these links and promo codes to unlock reserved tickets they can use to attend the premiere.

Amazon Studios: A burgeoning player in film and television, the site regularly hosts free television and movie screenings to generate buzz for new and upcoming projects.

Gofobo: This filmgoer-friendly resource offers tickets to advance screenings of upcoming films, as well as various themed sweepstakes giveaways like promotional movie swag and snack baskets. Users create their own account, which they will use to scan for screenings in or near their Zip code. The account also keeps track of their ticket requests.

Title: Should You Smoke (Food) Indoors?
Description:
My ears always perk up a bit when I run across something original for the kitchen. An internal thought process goes from something like there's probably a good reason why no one has ever done this before to how has no one ever done this before?

Devices that allow you to do a bit of smoking while indoors pop up every few years, and often end up being a bit too impractical to make many waves, or fun but very niche.

It’s easy to understand why manufacturers try. From nuts to cheese to ribs and brisket, people go nuts for smoked food. Moving things indoors does really practical things like letting those same people come in from the rain or snow on a cold day. Unfortunately, some indoor smokers can set your smoke alarm off with relationship-damaging frequency. Others simply don’t work very well.

Those very thoughts ran through my brain when I heard about a new electric indoor smoker from GE which I called in to test. Should we be smoking indoors? This oven had just enough promise to make me wonder if it might be worth one more try.

The first thing I discovered is that the GE Profile Smart Indoor Smoker (aka The Smart Indoor Pellet Smoker) is a honker at 16.25 inches high by 16.5 wide and 20.35 deep. It was easily the largest appliance on my kitchen counter, about twice the size of my microwave, Sparky Jr., whose spot it took. (Sparky took its temporary placement on top of the cooler like a champ.)

GE's countertop smoker. It's not small. GE

Opening the door reveals a cavity roughly a foot deep, a foot high, and eight inches wide. Small for a built-in oven, very small for a smoker, but hey, it's in my kitchen and not out on my cold, wet deck in Seattle. You feed standard barbecue wood pellets into a little hopper on the top, they drop into the interior and get toasty, then fall into a metal "waste bin" that's half filled with water, ensuring they are properly extinguished. There's a well laid out control panel on the front. A not-too-fussy mobile app gives you a degree of remote control if you want that. The temperature range of the smoker is 175 to 300 degrees Fahrenheit, a bit too low to allow it to pinch hit as a (non-smoking) countertop oven, which would be nice. It’s also important to state up-front that it retails for $1,000, though the price fluctuates a lot and has dipped as low as $500 at times.

Title: A Math Couple Solves a Major Group Theory Problem—After 20 Years of Work
Description:
The original version of this story appeared in Quanta Magazine.

In 2003, a German graduate student named Britta Späth encountered the McKay conjecture, one of the biggest open problems in the mathematical realm known as group theory. At first her goals were relatively modest: She hoped to prove a theorem or two that would make incremental progress on the problem, as many other mathematicians had done before her. But over the years, she was drawn back to it, again and again. Whenever she tried to focus on something else, she said, “it didn’t connect.”

There was a risk that such a single-minded pursuit of so difficult a problem could hurt her academic career, but Späth dedicated all her time to it anyway. It brought her to the office of Marc Cabanes, a mathematician now at the Institute of Mathematics of Jussieu in Paris who, inspired by her efforts, became consumed by the conjecture, too. While working together, the pair fell in love and eventually started a family.

The problem that absorbed them takes a key theme in mathematics and turns it into a concrete tool for group theorists. Math is full of enormously complicated abstract objects that are impossible to study in their entirety. But often, mathematicians have discovered, it’s enough to look at a small fragment of such an object to understand its broader properties. In the third century BC, for instance, the ancient Greek mathematician Eratosthenes estimated the circumference of the Earth—roughly 25,000 miles—by measuring shadows cast by the sun in just two cities about 500 miles apart. Similarly, when mathematicians want to understand an impossibly convoluted function, they might only need to look at how it behaves for a small subset of possible inputs. That can be enough to tell them what the function does for all possible inputs.

The McKay conjecture is another example of this principle. It says that if you want to formulate a thorough description of a group—an important mathematical entity that can get prohibitively difficult to study—you only need to look at a tiny piece of it.

While working together on the McKay conjecture, Britta Späth and Marc Cabanes fell in love and started a family. Photograph: Günther Späth/Quanta Magazine

After the conjecture was posed in the 1970s, dozens of mathematicians tried their hand at proving it. They made partial progress—and in the process they learned a great deal about groups, which are abstract objects that describe the various symmetries of a mathematical system. But a full proof seemed out of reach.

Then Späth came along. Now, 20 years after she first learned about the problem and more than a decade after she met Cabanes, the two mathematicians have finally completed the proof.

When the couple announced their result, their colleagues were in awe. “I wanted there to be parades,” said Persi Diaconis of Stanford University. “Years of hard, hard, hard work, and she did it, they did it.”

The Power of Primes

The McKay conjecture began with the observation of a strange coincidence.

John McKay—described by one friend as “brilliant, soft-spoken, and charmingly disorganized”—was known for his ability to spot numerical patterns in unexpected places. The Concordia University mathematician is perhaps most famous for his “monstrous moonshine” conjecture, which was proved in 1992 and established a deep connection between the so-called monster group and a special function from number theory.

Title: Fixed a mathematical problem of over a century ago which unites two fundamental laws of physics
Description:
A mathematical problem that had resisted for over a century - 125 years, to be precise - has finally been resolved by a team of scientists from the University of Michigan and other research institutes. It is, to be precise, the sixth problem of Hilbert, an ambitious challenge posed by the mathematician David Hilbert in 1900 with the Sibillino title of "mathematical treatment of the axioms of physics". Basically, Hilbert (Si) asked how it was possible to derive some laws of physics axiomatically, in particular those relating to the behavior of fluids on different spatial stairs: well, the three authors of the work just loaded on Arxiv claim to have successfully unified these laws, which could have profound implications in the field of fluidodynamics and improve our understanding of the atmosphere and oceans.

Hilbert's mathematical problem

The question raised Hilbert, roughly summarized, is this. There are three different discussion for the Moto of the fluids. The first is the microscopic one: with the laws of Newton's motorcycle, they can (at least) in principle follow the trajectories and behaviors of each of the particles that make up the fluid. The second is the mesoscopic one, provided by the Equation of Boltzmann, which describes the behavior of the fluid "statistically". Finally there is the macroscopic one, provided by the fluidodynamic equations of Euler and Navier-Stakes, which describe the behavior of the fluid "as a whole". The second part of the sixth problem of Hilbert is precisely relating to the derivation and unification of these three treatments from first axioms and in an organic and harmonious theory. And this is what Yu Deng, Zaher Hani and Xiao but, the three authors of the work just published, claim to have managed to do, deriving the macroscopic equations of the fluids starting from the laws of Newton and passing through the kinetic theory of Boltzmann.

All fault of time

Why did it take so much time to solve this mathematical problem? One of the main difficulties is linked to time, a subtle and complex entity whose understanding and treatment has been pursued for some time (sic!) The physicists. In particular, as Deng explains, some of the laws in question (those of Newton, for example) are symmetrical with respect to the temporal reversal, in the sense that they "work" whether the weather flows forward and backwards, that is, in other words, they do not identify a privileged direction for the passage of time. Our daily experience, however, tells us the opposite - we know that time always flows in one direction - and so they also make the laws of Boltzmann and thermodynamics, which precisely indicate a precise direction for the passage of time, from the past to the future, that is, (to be more technical) from a state of minor entropy to a state of greater entropy. The authors of the article say they have managed to understand exactly how, where, when and because this switch takes place that identifies a privileged direction for the passage of time, thus overcoming the paradox of temporal symmetry.

Simplification and resolution

Until now, a series of "partial solutions" had been proposed to the sixth problem of Hilbert, but the approach of the authors of the work just published has led to a finally more general formulation of the solution. In particular, the three have found a way to simplify the discussion of the equations of the motion of particles that interact repeatedly with each other (one can think of a fluid as a set of balls that moving constantly hit each other) and in this way, reducing the complexity of the problem, they managed to match all the mosaic tiles. But despite success, they are not yet satisfied: "The solution of Hilbert's problems - Hani said - is not yet complete. The importance of the sixth problem lies not only in the absomatization of the laws of physics, but also in understanding the implications of these mathematical models. We know that the models, at a certain point, at a certain spatial or temporal scale, cease to work. be placed in terms of understanding what happens when this happens ". Scientists are particularly interested, in particular, to understand what happens to even more microscopic stairs, when fluid equations lead to the so -called singularity, that is, to mathematical solutions that have no sense from the point of view of physics. It is not only academic itching: in many scenarios in the sectors of oceanography and science of the atmosphere, in fact, it is frequently runs into the singularity; And the work just published could help to understand how to deal with the issue. As the authors admit, however, it could still take a long time.

Title: What are the effects of measles and because it can be lethal
Description:
In Western Texas and in New Mexico the drop in vaccination rates has caused a new measles epidemic, which has so far been associated with two deaths. The first victim is a child not vaccinated in Texas, without previous health problems, at the end of February. Subsequently, on March 6, the health authorities of the new Mexico recorded the death of an adult individual, also in this case not vaccinated, which had been positive for measles after death.

Together with the epidemic, a lot of disinformation about measles is also spreading on social media. In the United States, many conservative and no-vax accounts minimize the severity of the virus, claiming for example that the child in Texas died of other causes. On X, the deputy of the Republican Party Marjorie Taylor Greene - known for its extremist and conspiracy positions - suggested organizing "measles party" to strengthen children's immunity to the virus, despite the local health officials explicitly not recommended them, calling them "crazy".

Morbillo can cause serious health problems. The disease exposes the risk of contracting other types of infections and sometimes it can also be fatal.

If most people today has never had to deal with measles, it is thanks to the vaccines introduced in 1963. According to some estimates, in the decade before the infection hit 3 to 4 million people per year only in the United States. Of these, about 48 thousand were hospitalized and 400-500 died every year.

Morbillo epidemic in the United States

The current Texas epidemic began in late January. The official data, updated to March 21, report 309 cases, with 40 hospitalizations. Most of the infected people live in the County of Gaines, where the vaccination rate for measles at kindergarten is 82%, a share significantly less than 95% necessary to protect a community from the disease. In the nearby county of Lea, in New Mexico, there have been 42 infected so far, with two hospitalizations. The vast majority of cases in both states are unvaccinated people. In total, 285 people in the United States got sick of measles throughout 2024; For 40% of them, a hospital hospitalization was necessary.

How the disease is manifested

Morbillo causes a rather characteristic skin eruption, which initially manifests itself with flat and red spots and degenerates with the appearance of larger spots. But it can also lead to much more serious damage: measles in fact is highly contagious and can be dangerous for infants, for small children and even for adults. The virus spreads through cough and sneezing shots and can resist in the environment up to two hours.

Title: Akira Kurosawa, 5 films to celebrate the master who came from the East
Description: Akira Kurosawa claimed that cinema contained many other arts within itself. Certainly almost nobody in the history of the seventh art has been able to represent this concept as well as him, born in Tokyo on March 23, 1910 and became during a very fertile and extraordinary career, one of the greatest and influential directors of all time. Kurosawa gave us an incredible amount of masterpieces, a films that sometimes sanctioned the birth of a precise genre, others have been able to influence others and often have also gone further, creating a real universe in its own right. Few authors are on a par for depth of analysis and writing, by visual power, dynamism, for the ability to be a point of contact between the West and the East, moving between epic and normality, outlining a humanity always in the balance between heroism and fragility, between light and darkness. Today that the anniversary of his birth occurs, honoring him with a top 5 of his most important films is a task not only heavy, but also very difficult, so much is the quality expressed by the Japanese director, still today a monument of the Rising Sun. Certainly what he created still lives today in films, TV series, anime, manga, graphic novels, painting and literature. In some cases it can be said that without him these universes would not be what we know and love today.

Title: Pretty Woman after 35 years continues to be a myth, despite everything
Description:
After 35 years Pretty Woman remains an absolute cinematographic myth, in spite of the very profound changes of society and above all the image of the woman. Still, the endless success of this film tells us a lot about how much a certain type of cinema and narration continues to exercise a unique charm, even when it would be to be relegated to oblivion.

In fact, it is impossible to split Pretty Woman from what the American society had been up to that moment, the narration on the small and large screen that represented fashions, principles, more or less declared ideals. The 80s are the years of consumerism, of popular glamor, of the supermodels that begin to become absolute different, of the pop cultures and the extreme sexualization of all its elements.

But they are also the years of reaganism, of the woman who becomes more and more declination of male desire, a body to possess and admire. Meanwhile, in the meantime, in spite of female characters that is anything but meek (see the money, the success, the success, the only real points of reference, the great dream that everyone must ride. It is what you have, you are what you are aesthetically and poverty is worse than everything, even of cruelty. Description:
Rivasi is also a board game that is often used in the description of "overlaying." The binary values ​​of white and black are analogies for 0 and 1 for qubits, and in quantum mechanics these states are superimposed. In other words, one piece is in a state where it is either white or black. More importantly, the relationship between the observer and the game. In the world of classical mechanics, the gods are rivasi, and we observe the rules from the outside. For example, we objectively discover the rule that if we type white, the stones between them will turn white. In other words, the observer is outside the physical system and has no effect on the system. On the other hand, in the world of quantum mechanics, you are also a player, and your own observations and actions affect the game itself. It feels like nature is white and you are black, and you are fighting each other. This is the essential feature of quantum mechanics.

A sci-fi love story set in Kyoto in the near future. As the protagonist, who comes from the future, tries to change the past, the boundary between reality and virtual reality becomes blurred, and the truth about the world is revealed. PHOTOGRAPH BY DAIGO NAGAO

Distributed by: Toho

Storage device "Altara" and digital twin

What's interesting about the film "HELLO WORLD" is the worldview of the digital twin, created in the memory device called "Altara" that appears in the story. Altara continues to accumulate a huge amount of data, and overlays and remembers various historical events, from the past to the future, that is, states of various time axes. This is very similar to the "history state" that is referred to in quantum computer research. History state refers to the concept that a state at a certain time can be obtained by measuring the states of various steps from the initial time of a calculation by superimposing them. Therefore, "Altara" which remembers various time axes states can be said to have realized its history state in a sense. However, it would be difficult to create an actual digital twin with such precision. It's like calculating all atoms on Earth.

Kenji, a high school student who is good at math, enters a fierce battle in a virtual world after being invited by a senior he admires to work part-time. Kenji's head is similar to a quantum computer!

The first and most interesting thing about Summer Wars is that the main character, Koiso Kenji, is studying Shore's algorithms. Shore's algorithm was a major catalyst for quantum computer research in the 1990s, and was created to efficiently solve prime factorization. In the work, when the virtual world "OZ" is taken over, Kenji works on prime factorization to decipher code. There is a scene where a supercomputer is cooled down on the ice of a fishing boat and calculates it (it's just a fisherman's computer), but Kenji's mind, who solves a problem that he still couldn't solve, could be called a quantum computer. The setting that if a majority of OZ users are taken over, the entire world will also be taken over is similar to decentralized consensus building in blockchain technology. Title: How to create a bicycle city? --The future emerges from Western efforts
Description:
The "traffic jam tax" introduced on January 5th had a major impact on New York City. Most notably, the ease of congestion in Midtown and Lower Manhattan.

Additionally, the increase in pedestrians around the area has benefited retailers with brick and mortar stores. As a result of the increase in people taking the subway, crime on trains has decreased. The city is also benefiting financially as traffic jam taxes average $9 (about 1,300 yen) per passenger car at peak times and over $21.60 (about 3,200 yen) for heavy trucks. In the first month of introduction, revenue was $48.6 million (approximately 7 billion yen), significantly exceeding the initial forecast of $40 million (approximately 6 billion yen).

News of the remarkable success of the traffic tax has faded into the shadows after President Trump announced he would abolish the program, but many experts see the president's attempts not going to be successful.

Cyclists talk about changes in the city

Traffic taxes have made the lives of cyclists moving across the streets of New York more comfortable. Commuters, delivery workers, delivery companies, and hobbyists on bicycles -- the situation in places that everyone riding their bikes in Manhattan once considered dangerous is gradually improving.

Recently, I was checking social media and saw countless videos and photos posted by old New York friends, a Central Park-based race team and famous bicycle influencers around the city. What everyone was saying was that riding a bike has become more fun, less stressful and easier than ever in Manhattan after the traffic jam tax was introduced.

"When I was riding my bike in the heart of town, I was forced to act aggressively to defend myself," says Anna Berlanga, organizer at Transportation Alternatives, a Bronx-based nonprofit. The organization is working to promote the use of bicycles, walking and public transport. "But once the traffic jam tax was introduced, there's no need for that. It would be nice to have a small bike bell. It's completely different from before."

A cyclist in Kips Bay, New York City. Photograph: Noam Galai/Getty Images

Queens-based bicycle delivery guy, Quentin, also agreed with Berlanga's idea, saying New York's streets are now more spacious than before.

"I feel like I have a lot of space right now." Quentin says this, admits that he misses the presence of traffic jams, in that his work has sometimes been interesting. "You can see that the streets in Midtown are particularly spacious and there are very few cars running."

Delivery workers aren't the only ones who enjoy the roads of the city with reduced traffic. The city's bicycle sharing platform CitiBike has not yet released user information for January, but it appears that the number of users is increasing compared to previous years.

"This winter has been a colder winter than usual. Even so, since the introduction of traffic jam tax, the number of people riding bicycles has increased." says Ken Podgiva, president and CEO of Bike New York, a nonprofit organization that promotes cycling. "But it's only going to be really interesting once it gets warmer. I think we'll see a dramatic change with fewer cars and bikes filling the streets of the city."

Title: Start with Earth Day. 12 recommended latest eco goods that will help you make your environment more suitable: WIRED SHOPPING GUIDE
Description:
毎年、世界各地で地球環境についてのイベントが企画されているアースデイだが、そもそもアースデイとはどんな日なのか、どのようにして始まったのか、簡単におさらいしたい。そして、身近なところでもアクションを起こしたいという人のために、環境に配慮して開発された最新のエコグッズコレクションを紹介する。ぜひ、購入する際の参考にしてほしい。

1. アースデイとはどんな日？

アースデイは毎年4月22日。地球に感謝する記念日であり、また環境について考え、行動する日でもある。具体的に何をしなければならないといった決まりはなく、地球環境のために何らかのアクションを起こす、あるいは、そのきっかけとすることに意義がある。世界各地で多くのイベントが催され、ここ日本でも東京や大阪などで開催されており、目にしている人も多いだろう。

2. アースデイはどのようにして始まった？

4月22日がアースデイとされたのは、いまから半世紀以上前の1970年のこと。人々の意識を高めるために「環境の日」をつくるべきという、米国のゲイロード・ネルソン上院議員（当時）の呼びかけに対し、スタンフォード大学の学生だったデニス・ヘイズが応えたことが始まりだ。

その動きはすぐに全米へと広がり、年ごとにさまざまなイベントやキャンペーンが催されるようになった。そして、やがては世界的なムーブメントとなったのである。

3. アースデイの今年のテーマは？

昨今のアースデイでは特定の環境問題にフォーカスすべく、毎年世界共通のテーマが設定されている。スタートから55年を経た2025年のテーマは、「Our Power, Our Planet」。太陽光や風力、水力、地熱といった再生可能エネルギーを活用する取り組みに注力し、エネルギーの安定供給や温室効果ガスの排出抑制、つまりはさらなる地球温暖化対策を目指すというものだ。

4. 地球環境のために選ぶべきエコグッズ12選

さて、ここでは選ぶことが地球環境を守ることにつながるプロダクトを幅広くピックアップした。環境に配慮した素材を使用するものから、工場の電力をすべて風力でまかなう企業のものまで、かたちは違えど、そのどれもがエココンシャスなアイテムである。地球環境のためにすでにアクションを起こしているという人にも、このアースデイをきっかけに始めたいという人にもおすすめだ。

◆

環境負荷の少ない素材と構造を採用

aarke「Purifier」

aarke（アールケ）は、ふたりのインダストリアルデザイナーによって設立されたスウェーデンのプレミアム・キッチンウェアブランド。ここで紹介するのは、ブランドを代表するアイテムのひとつであるカラフェ型浄水器「Purifier」だ。

セルフクリーニング＆浄水機能を装備した水筒が、LARQ（ラーク）による「Bottle PureVis」。特許技術であるPureVisテクノロジーにより、キャップ部分のUV-C（深紫外線）LEDから発する深紫外線で大腸菌などの生物学的汚染物質を最大99％除去し、水質を向上させると謳う。

Title: If you want to extend the lifespan of your iPhone, you can also try not to fully charge it.
Description:
Many modern smartphones can be used all day long on a single full charge. Even in the middle range and entry-level models, there is not much need to carry a spare battery with you or charge it multiple times a day. Therefore, rather than worrying about whether the battery will last for a day or not, there is a tendency to emphasize how well the battery can be kept for several years, or "battery life."

One way to extend battery life is to not keep it fully charged for a long time. This is because if the battery is fully charged, it will put a load on the battery, causing it to deteriorate more quickly in the long term.

Furthermore, thanks to the function "Battery Charging Optimization", iPhones may already have learned charging patterns. If you turn on this function, it will adjust the function so that even if you charge it overnight, it won't reach 100% until the morning.

How to set the upper charge limit

If you want to manually control the battery, there is a way to use the "Charge Limit" function. This function is a function that allows you to stop the battery charging at 95%, and is useful for reducing the load on the battery.

For iPhone 15 and later models, if you go to Settings > Battery > Charge, you can set the charging limit in 5% increments in the 80% to 100% range.

Is there a time when to charge to 100%?

According to Apple, using a charging limit can extend battery life, and depending on how you use it, iOS may automatically recommend it. Even if you only charge up to 95%, the iPhone has its advantages in the long run.

That said, even if you leave it in a 100% state and still plug it in, there's no need to be so nervous, says CNET reporter Patrick Holland.

"Full charge is not the only factor that affects battery life. Apple and other manufacturers use software to reduce various factors and make it easier for users to control if necessary. Balance is important, so there's no need to overly fear 100% charging."

Furthermore, even if the upper charging limit is set, in rare cases, the battery may be charged to 100%. According to Apple, "Even if the battery is set to below 100%, it can sometimes be charged to 100% to properly measure the remaining battery level."

Title: Browser Use, the tool making it easier for AI ‘agents’ to navigate websites, raises $17M
Description:
We may not have an agreed-upon definition of AI “agent” yet, but a multitude of startups want to create “agentic” tools to automate various tasks online. One such firm, Browser Use, has attracted a ton of interest from developers and investors thanks to its solution that makes websites more “readable” for AI agents.

Browser Use told TechCrunch that it has raised a sizable $17 million seed funding round led by Felicis’ Astasia Myers with participation from Paul Graham, A Capital, and Nexus Venture Partners. The company’s funding hasn’t previously been reported.

Browser use’s website.

Browser Use, part of Y Combinator’s 2025 winter batch, has gained notoriety in recent months. Chinese startup Butterfly Effect’s use of Brower Use in its viral Manus tool drove awareness to new heights.

Magnus Müller and Gregor Zunic founded Browser Use last year through ETH Zurich’s Student Project House accelerator. Müller had been working on web-scraping tools for years, and met Zunic in 2024 while the pair were getting their master’s degrees in data science. Together, according to Müller, they came up with the idea of combining web scraping with data science to prompt a browser to perform a task.

Müller and Zunic built a Browser Use demo in five weeks — and it took off. Subsequently, they open-sourced it.

Browser Use essentially breaks down the buttons and elements of a website into a more digestible, “text-like” format for agents. This helps the agents understand the different options and make decisions autonomously.

“A lot of agents rely on vision-based systems and try and navigate websites through screenshots, and in [the] process, things break,” Müller said. “We convert [websites] into something agents can understand. This approach means we can run the same tasks again and again at a cheaper cost.”

There’s an increasing number of AI companies that want to make their agents interact with websites more gracefully, and Müller thinks Browser Use can become a “fundamental layer” serving this need. He added that more than 20 companies in the current Y Combinator Winter batch used Browser Use for their own requirements.

“There are companies coming to us and saying, ‘What can we do to make it easier for agents to navigate our website?’” Müller said. “There are sites — for example, LinkedIn — that change the way the website works all the time, so agents often fail on sites like those.”

According to Myers, Felicis has been actively looking at the AI agents space for the past several years, and Browser Use felt like the right opportunity to grow the firm’s portfolio there. She said that the company’s founding team — and its open-source-first approach — sealed the deal

“We think web AI agents are the next frontier that really helps with the end-to-end automation of human tasks,” Myers told TechCrunch. “[W]eb AI agents are this dynamic bridge between static pre-trained models that are mostly text-focused in the ever-changing digital landscape.”
